intro: Fraxinus pennsylvanica subsp. oregona, commonly known as the Oregon ash, is a deciduous tree native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It typically grows to a height of 15–30 meters and has a broad, spreading crown. The leaves are opposite, simple, and ovate with a serrated margin, turning yellow in the fall. Its bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in panicles, followed by winged fruits that disperse its seeds.
